thread.author: devin-ai-integration
thread.body: üö© **Cache file committed to repo as .cache_project_schema.json with real project data** The file `.agent/.cache_project_schema.json` is committed to the repository. This file is also the runtime cache target (`CACHE_FILE` at `commands.js:18`), meaning `fetchProjectData` will read from and write to this committed file. Two implications: 1. The committed file acts as a pre-seeded cache. Since `fetchProjectData` checks `mtimeMs` against `Date.now()`, the committed file's mtime on a fresh clone will be the clone time, which will be within the 10-minute TTL ‚Äî so it will be used as cache on first run after clone, even though it may be days or weeks old. 2. Every time the cache refreshes, it modifies a tracked file, creating unintended git diffs. Developers will see `.cache_project_schema.json` as modified in `git status` after running any command that triggers a cache refresh. This file should likely be in `.gitignore` rather than committed. --- *Was this helpful? React with üëç or üëé to provide feedback.*

The committed file acts as a pre-seeded cache. Since `fetchProjectData` checks `mtimeMs` against `Date.now()`, the committed file's mtime on a fresh clone will be the clone time, which will be within the 10-minute TTL ‚Äî so it will be used as cache on first run after clone, even though it may be days or weeks old. 2. Every time the cache refreshes, it modifies a tracked file, creating unintended git diffs. This file should likely be in `.gitignore` rather than committed. --- *Was this helpful? React with üëç or üëé to provide feedback.*
